title: Eucephalus engelmannii
text:
Eucephalus engelmannii is a North American species in the <a href="Asteraceae">aster family</a> known by the common name Engelmann's aster. It is native to the United States and Canada from <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a> and <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a> to far northern <a href="California">California</a> and <a href="Colorado">Colorado</a>.
"Eucephalus engelmannii" grows in mountain woods and meadows. It is a perennial herb growing from a woody <a href="caudex">caudex</a> and sending a slender, branching, hairy stem to a maximum height near 1.5 meters (5 feet). The mostly hairless leaves are generally <a href="Leaf%20shape">oval</a> and up to 10 centimeters (4 inches) long, with the lowest ones much reduced. The <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a> holds several <a href="Head%20%28botany%29">flower heads</a> lined in keeled, pointed, hairy-edged <a href="bract">phyllaries</a> with purplish margins at the tips. Each head has 8-13 white to pinkish or light violet <a href="ray%20florets">ray florets</a> each up to 2 centimeters long, surrounding yellow disc florets. The fruit is a hairy <a href="achene">achene</a>.
